column1: Some factors that contribute to the development of a hernia include: - Chronic constipation - Chronic cough - Heavy lifting - Obesity - Straining to urinate because of an enlarged prostate Femoral hernias tend to occur more often in women than in men.
You may see a bulge in the upper thigh just below the groin.
Sometimes, the first symptoms are sudden groin pain, abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
The best way to tell if there is a hernia is to have your health care provider perform a physical exam.
Treatment depends on the symptoms present with the hernia.
If you feel sudden pain in your groin, a piece of intestine may be stuck in the hernia.
If the intestine or other tissue becomes stuck, a portion of the intestine may need to be removed.

Call your health care provider or local emergency number (911) or go to the emergency room right away if: - You suddenly develop pain in the hernia, and the hernia cannot be pushed back into the abdomen using gentle pressure.
Call your health care provider if you have a bulge in the upper thigh next to the groin.
